shell

Class GMapShell

  • java.lang.Object
    • shell.GMapShell

  • public class GMapShell
extends java.lang.Object
    Sends queries to Google Distance Matrix API and Google Geocoding API, and receives response values in return. In order to use this program, you need a developer account on Google API Console, and one API key to pass as a value for the apiKey parameter. To get this source code compiled, follow the instructions in ReadMe.html
    Since:
    24/02/2015
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Nguyen V. Tan

    • Constructor Detail

      • GMapShell

        public GMapShell()

    • Method Detail

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        Executes this program by this following command: java -cp $CLASSPATH $jarfile shell.GMapShell --apiKey AIza..your_own_API-Key...; whereas $CLASSPATH contains all required paths containing .class files, and $jarfile is the actual .jar file (e. g. gmapshell.jar or gmap_standalone.jar) which contains shell/GMapShell.class. If you want to, you can use these following options:
        --help
        --language determines the response language
        --unit IMPERIAL (in feet or miles)|METRIC (in metres or kilometres)
        --mode determines the way of travel (driving|walking|bicycling|transit) --fuzzy false|true:
        determines whether the user wants to enter simple names of places (details like street number, or postal code are not required), or specific addresses. if fuzzy is true, the user will have to give specific data like
        • country
        • town
        • postal code
        • street
        • street number
        For legal reasons, I may have no permission to upload gmap_standalone.jar, because it contains .class files which haven't been created by myself. Unfortunately, gmapshell.jar is very difficult to execute because it doesn't contain any .class files, or libraries which this application actually depends on. So, in order to use this program, you will have to download this entire project, and compile it from source. Before you do that, download, compile and install all depending projects and libraries (more information on compilation and installation in ReadMe.html)
